Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Silicon Photonic Integrated Devices Open-Access Foundry / Fabrication Facility. To be held at the OSA Headquarters in Washington DC September, 2013.

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective: The proposed project seeks financial support for a one-day Workshop on Silicon Photonic Integrated Devices Open-Access Foundry / Fabrication Facility to be held at the OSA Headquarters in Washington DC in September 2013.

Intellectual Merit: The Workshop is to discuss the needs for a U.S. based open-access fabrication facility for photonic integrated circuits. Discussion at the workshop will provide further specific guidance on materials, the range of processes, and integration. The Workshop involves a sequence of invited talks and open discussions concluding with a closed session for government invitees only. Possible models for a U.S. based fab facility, and corresponding funding / operating requirements will be discussed.

Broader Impacts: The Workshop will bring together leading experts in optoelectronics to discuss the low-volume, but scalable, manufacturing of state-of-the-art photonic devices, including those critical to communications infrastructure, large-data networks, metrology, sensors, and imaging. Key speakers are to describe cutting-edge silicon photonic technology with decision makers from government laboratories, industry and funding agencies. The exchange of ideas and collaboration possibilities are expected to facilitate consensus and serve the research needs of the silicon photonics community and training of a US workforce in this area. Initiatives generated a result of this Workshop will benefit the ongoing research and training of graduate students across the country, the efforts of small businesses, as well as the largest industrial concerns in this research area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
OIDA—the Optoelectronics Industry Development Association— hosted a one-day workshop on behalf of the EECS Division of the U.S. National Science Foundation. It was held at OSA headquarters in Washington DC, on September 4, 2013. Guests included representatives from government agencies, university researchers, and companies with interests in integrated photonics, particularly those using the platform generally known as "silicon photonics."
The aim of the workshop was to review the capabilities to fabricate silicon photonics as a foundry service, particularly from a facility within the U.S. The workshop focused on the front-end wafer processing, as opposed to the back-end assembly and test processes, although it was understood that the entire ecosystem is important to the success of silicon photonics. Presenters were asked to summarize the facilities that are available: who, where, what capabilities, and what intellectual property and business models.The workshop was intended to bring together key players, collect information, and discuss the opportunities for a silicon photonics foundry within the U.S.

Alan Willner, professor at the University of Southern California, and co-chair of the National Academies Committee on Harnessing Light, presented a case for a U.S.-based open foundry, for university and industrial device development. Willner noted that the U.S. is still the leader in U.S. patents on monolithically integrated optoelectronic devices (OEICs), but that there is a 6-month lead time to obtain prototypes from a foundry service, which is invariablylocated offshore. Willner’s challenge was essentially the key question of the workshop: what would be a cost-effective model for a U.S.-based open foundry for fabricating silicon photonics.
